    • The device uses GPS and voice recognition technology to provide the user with information such as distance to the pin, green size, and pin placement.
• The device can also be used to record and store golf course data, such as the location of hazards and fairway boundaries.
    • This data can be used to provide the golfer with recommendations for future shots based on their past performance.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Problem:** Existing design rule checking (DRC) methods for integrated circuits (ICs) with both memory and logic components have limitations:

    * * Traditional methods flag many false DRC errors in memory regions because they apply stricter logic rules to memory circuits.
    * * Manual error filtering is time-consuming and prone to overlooking real errors.
    * * Masking techniques, while eliminating false errors, can miss real errors at the memory-logic interface.
    * * Existing solutions don't effectively address the need for different design rules for different circuit types.

* **Solution:** The invention introduces a novel DRC system and method that accurately identifies and reports errors by applying customized design rules tailored to specific circuit regions:

    * * It distinguishes between logic and various memory regions (e.g., SRAM, ROM) within the IC layout.
    * * It uses standard logic design rules for logic regions and customized rules for memory regions.
    * * Customized memory rules are derived by modifying standard logic rules to accommodate the more lenient design constraints of memory circuits.
    * * This approach eliminates false errors and ensures accurate error reporting for both logic and memory regions.

* **Implementation:** The system leverages a conventional computer system with specialized software routines and libraries:

    * * It analyzes memory bit cell layouts to identify violations against standard logic rules.
    * * Based on these violations, it modifies the standard logic rules to create customized memory rules.
    * * During DRC, it applies the appropriate rules based on the identified circuit region (logic or specific memory type).
    * * The system can be implemented using standard GDS formatted data and common programming languages.

* **Benefits:** The invention offers significant advantages over prior art methods:

    * * Accurate error reporting by applying the right rules to the right regions.
    * * Elimination of false errors, reducing manual verification effort.
    * * Improved efficiency and faster design cycles.
    * * Applicability to various IC designs, including those with multiple memory types.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Waveguide Hologram (WGH) Illuminators:**
    • Offer advantages over conventional lens systems for illuminating objects like SLMs and holograms.
    • Provide compact, rugged, and efficient illumination with minimal stray light.

• **Advantages of WGH Illuminators:**
    • Compact size compared to bulky lens systems.
    • High diffraction efficiency, approaching 99% in ideal cases.
    • Excellent stray light suppression due to total internal reflection.

• **Challenges and Solutions:**
    • **Alignment Sensitivity:** Addressed by firmly attaching the source or using a broad source.
    • **Illumination Depletion:** Compensated by non-uniform hologram recording or post-recording correction.
    • **Two-Sided Emission:** Mitigated using absorbing paint, mirrors, or off-axis illumination.

• **Applications and Features:**
    • Effective for illuminating SLMs, enabling polarization modulation techniques.
    • Can be used with coherent or incoherent light sources.
    • Offer high spectral selectivity, achieving resolutions of 2-5 Å. 
</summary>

<summary>
• **Purpose of the Invention:**
	• Non-destructive testing of dynamoelectric machine rotors (e.g., electric motors and generators).
	• Economical and reliable measurement of rotor resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew.
	• Identification of rotor defects.
	• Automatic pass/fail determinations.

• **Key Features of the Apparatus:**
	• Test head with exciting means to magnetize the rotor.
	• Voltage sensing means to measure induced voltage.
	• Current sensing means to monitor excitation current.
	• Skew sensing means to determine effective electrical skew.

• **Data Acquisition and Processing:**
	• Sample and hold circuit synchronized with excitation current.
	• Analog-to-digital conversion of sampled signals.
	• Data processor for initial data processing and calculation of test values.
	• Control processor for final data processing, statistical analysis, and control functions.

• **Rotor Testing Procedure:**
	• Rotor is placed on the test head and retracted into the test position.
	• Rotor is rotated within the test head's magnetic field.
	• Voltage, current, and skew signals are sampled and digitized.
	• Resistance, reactance, and effective skew are calculated.

• **Pass/Fail Determination:**
	• Calculated values are compared to predetermined thresholds.
	• Pass/fail indication is provided to the operator.
	• Statistical data is stored for analysis.

• **Advantages of the Dual Fixture System:**
	• Increased testing efficiency.
	• Reduced operator setup time.
	• Cost-effectiveness due to shared processing system.

• **Clutch Mechanism for Rotor Positioning:**
	• Allows easy mounting of the rotor in the extended position.
	• Securely holds the rotor during rotation in the retracted position.

• **Overall Benefits:**
	• Improved quality control of dynamoelectric machine rotors.
	• Early detection of rotor defects.
	• Enhanced manufacturing processes and product reliability.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document describes a security mechanism for mobile devices that allows third-party applications to run while protecting the device from malicious code.
    * It achieves this by using a combination of digital certificates, managed libraries, and a runtime framework.
    * The system ensures that only trusted code can access sensitive resources, while untrusted code is restricted to a controlled environment.
* The document also outlines a process for verifying and signing third-party applications before they are made available on an electronic marketplace.
    * This process involves inspecting the application's code for potential security vulnerabilities and ensuring that it only uses approved libraries.
    * Once verified, the application is packaged and digitally signed to guarantee its authenticity and integrity.
* The proposed system aims to provide a balance between openness and security, enabling a rich ecosystem of third-party applications while safeguarding the integrity of the mobile device and its data.
    * By restricting direct access to native resources and enforcing code verification, the system mitigates the risks associated with running untrusted code.
    * This approach allows mobile device manufacturers to offer a more secure and controlled platform for third-party developers.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Prior Art Problems:**
    * Existing smart cards, often used for credit cards and ATMs, are prone to damage from bending due to their rigid structure.
    * Securing the antenna and chip with glue or mechanical means adds complexity and cost to the manufacturing process.
    * Traditional manufacturing methods using molds increase tooling and production expenses.

* **The Invention:**
    * A low-cost, easily constructed identification card with an embedded antenna and chip for enhanced protection.
    * Features two shock-absorbing layers, potentially containing printed information (indicia).
    * Incorporates two rigid outer layers for structural support and protection, distributing external forces to safeguard electronic components.

* **Card Construction:**
    * A core layer made of silica-filled polyolefin (e.g., TESLIN® sheet) is pre-shrunk.
    * Alkyd resin spids and a silver-epoxy antenna are printed onto the core layer.
    * An integrated circuit chip is connected to the antenna.

* **Layering and Bonding:**
    * A bottom sheet of silica-filled polyolefin is bonded to the core layer using a co-polyester adhesive (e.g., Transilwrap® TXP(3)).
    * Recesses in the adhesive accommodate the thicker IC chips.
    * A carboxylated polyethylene hot melt adhesive (e.g., Transilwrap® KRTY) secures the IC chip to the bottom layer.

* **Protective Layers:**
    * Two transparent polymer layers (e.g., polyester, polycarbonate) are added for mechanical strength.
    * Adhesive layers secure the polymer layers to the core and bottom layers.

* **Image-Receiving Layer:**
    * An image-receiving layer, compatible with dye diffusion thermal transfer printing, is applied to the polymer layers.
    * This layer can accommodate personalized information, such as portraits or barcodes.

* **Protective and Security Features:**
    * A protective layer, often biaxially oriented polyester, safeguards the image-receiving layer and prevents dye bleeding.
    * Security features like low cohesivity layers, UV-sensitive inks, or optically variable inks can be incorporated.

* **Alternative Embodiment:**
    * An inkjet receiver coating can be applied to designated areas of the core layer for personalization.
    * This eliminates the need for a separate image-receiving layer and protective layer.

* **Advantages:**
    * Enhanced durability

<summary>
* **The Problem:** Traditional FIFO queues are inefficient in functional memories because updates require copying the entire queue.
    * Functional memories use a "copy-on-write" approach, making queue updates expensive.
    * Existing implementations, like double-ended lists, don't suit this approach.
    * A more efficient solution is needed for functional memory environments.

* **The Proposed Solution:** Implement a FIFO queue using a balanced tree structure with a maximum node size.
    * Additions target the first non-full node on the left edge, deletions target the rightmost leaf node.
    * New nodes are created to maintain balance, ensuring all leaf nodes are at the same level.
    * This approach reduces copying to a logarithmic function of the queue length.

* **Performance Enhancements:** Introduce a header node and an inversion bit for further optimization.
    * The header node points to the beginning, end, and middle tree structure of the queue.
    * This allows for adding and deleting entire nodes at once, reducing update frequency.
    * An inversion bit enables constant-time queue reversal by reinterpreting the tree structure.

* **Advantages and Applications:** The invention offers several benefits and potential use cases.
    * Faster and more space-efficient updates compared to traditional methods.
    * Constant-time queue inversion enables versatile double-ended queue operations.
    * Suitable for functional memory environments where efficient updates are crucial.
</summary>

<summary>
• **EPROM Device Using DRAM Technology:**
    • This invention leverages existing DRAM manufacturing processes to create embedded EPROM devices.
    • It utilizes the DRAM storage capacitor as the coupling capacitor for the EPROM cell, eliminating the need for specialized and costly fabrication techniques. 

• **Stress Effect Programmable Read Only Memory (SEPROM):**
    • This invention introduces a novel type of EPROM that utilizes the permanent changes in transistor properties caused by electrical stresses (like hot carrier effects) to store data.
    • SEPROM devices can be manufactured using standard IC technologies, making them ideal for embedded applications and security purposes.

• **Advantages over Conventional EPROM:**
    • Both the DRAM-based EPROM and SEPROM offer cost-effectiveness due to their compatibility with existing manufacturing processes.
    • They also operate at lower voltages compared to conventional EPROMs, simplifying supporting circuitry requirements. 
</summary>

<summary>
* **Background:**
    * Feedback control, used in applications like automatic guidance vehicles, relies on feedback gains (P, I, D) to calculate correction amounts.
    * Traditional methods like the limit sensitivity process face challenges in accurately detecting self-sustaining vibrations, crucial for determining optimal gain values.
    * This invention aims to provide a more efficient and accurate method for determining feedback gains.
* **Proposed Method:**
    * The method involves iteratively adjusting and evaluating feedback gains to achieve desired control characteristics.
    * It utilizes evaluation functions tailored to each gain type (P, I, D) to assess control performance based on error analysis.
    * The method eliminates the need for complex analytical processes, simplifying gain optimization.
* **Evaluation Functions:**
    * **Proportional Gain (P):** Evaluated using the ratio of the error curve length to the measurement time, aiming for a value close to unity for optimal stability.
    * **Integral Gain (I):** Assessed by integrating the error over time, with a target value of zero indicating high control accuracy.
    * **Differential Gain (D):** Evaluated using the integral of the absolute error, striving for a value close to zero to ensure optimal response and stability.
* **Implementation:**
    * The method can be implemented in real-time, continuously adjusting gains as the system operates.
    * It allows for flexible gain adjustment strategies, including predefined step sizes or adaptive adjustments based on evaluation function behavior.
    * The invention provides a robust and adaptable solution for optimizing feedback control systems across various applications. 
</summary>

<summary>
* **Object of the Invention:**
    * To provide a compact zoom lens with a small F-number, high zoom ratio, standard image angle at the wide-angle end, and high optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.

* **Background:**
    * Existing zoom lenses for photographic and video cameras struggle to balance high relative aperture and zoom range with compact size and good optical performance.
    * Video cameras, especially 8mm models with smaller image sensors (1/2 inch), demand high relative aperture due to low sensor sensitivity.
    * Conventional 4-unit zoom lenses can achieve F-numbers of 1.4-1.6 but often have long total lengths (10-12 times the effective picture frame diagonal).

* **Key Features of the Invention:**
    * Employs a specific 5-unit configuration with positive, negative, negative, positive, and positive power units from front to rear.
    * Achieves a compact design with a total length shorter than 10 times the effective picture frame diagonal (L=9.13φA to 9.19φA).
    * Maintains high optical performance throughout the zooming range by carefully controlling aberrations.

* **Design Constraints and Solutions:**
    * **Condition (1):** Controls the rear surface curvature of the first lens in the fourth unit to balance spherical aberration and coma.
    * **Condition (2):** Determines the refractive power ratio of the second lens to the entire fifth unit for optimal spherical aberration correction.
    * **Condition (3):** Sets the refractive power ratio between the fourth and fifth lenses in the fifth unit to balance astigmatism and coma.
    * **Condition (4):** Specifies the Abbe numbers of the first and sixth lenses in the fifth unit for balanced longitudinal and lateral chromatic aberration correction.
    * **Condition (5):** Optimizes the refractive power of the second unit to minimize aberration variation during zooming while maintaining a compact size.

* **Specific Lens Unit Designs:**
    * **Fourth Lens Unit:** Bi-convex lens with a strongly curved rear surface for afocal light beam output.
    * **Fifth Lens Unit:** Complex 6-element design with specific lens shapes and air spacing to correct residual aberrations from the zoom section.

* **Numerical Examples:**
    * Four specific numerical examples are provided with detailed lens data, demonstrating the practical implementation of the invention.

<summary>
* **Problem:** Existing methods for detecting elementary particles have limitations:
    * They require prior knowledge of signal rates to choose between detecting individual particles or integrating signals.
* **Solution:** A new method and device are proposed to overcome these limitations.
    * The key innovation is discharging the charge pulse from the detector on the low-voltage side.
* **Advantages of Low-Voltage Discharge:**
    * Improves signal-to-noise ratio by minimizing interference from leakage current.
    * Enables simpler detection of small signals.
* **Dual Detection Modes:**
    * **AC Path:** Amplifies individual signals for low rates using a fast amplifier.
    * **DC Path:** Integrates signals for high rates using a slow amplifier.
* **Signal Separation:**
    * Achieved using capacitors, inductors, or filters to direct signals based on their rate.
    * Allows for simultaneous detection in both modes within an overlapping rate range.
* **Detection of Uncharged Particles:**
    * Achieved by doping or coating the detector material with a converter material.
* **Detector Material:**
    * Materials enabling fast charge transport at room temperature, such as diamond, are preferred.
* **Applications:**
    * Particle accelerators, reactor installations, medical diagnostic devices (X-ray, CT).
</summary>

<summary>
• **Prior Art Limitations:**
    • Existing spin-checking fixtures for driven disc assemblies were slow, inefficient, and required manual operation.
    • They lacked external indicators to signal whether the tested assembly passed or failed.

• **Invention Overview:**
    • This invention presents an improved apparatus for automatically spin-checking driven disc assemblies.
    • It features an automated process that eliminates manual intervention and provides clear pass/fail indications to the operator.

• **Apparatus Structure:**
    • The apparatus comprises a rigid test enclosure with a stationary ring and a movable ring.
    • A torque motor rotates the driven disc assembly, while a servo motor controls the movable ring's position.

• **Operational Sequence:**
    • The driven disc assembly is mounted between the rings, and the movable ring applies frictional engagement.
    • The torque motor attempts to rotate the assembly, and the movable ring gradually retracts.

• **Measurement and Evaluation:**
    • Sensors measure the distance between the rings and the rotation of the assembly.
    • The difference in distance readings, representing warpage, is compared to a standard value.

• **Pass/Fail Determination:**
    • If the warpage is within tolerance, the apparatus signals a "pass" and releases the assembly.
    • If the warpage exceeds the limit, the apparatus signals a "fail" and halts operation.

• **Advantages:**
    • The automated process enhances efficiency and reduces operator involvement.
    • External indicators provide clear pass/fail results, minimizing errors.

• **Additional Benefits:**
    • The apparatus enables data collection for statistical process control.
    • It improves the accuracy and reliability of driven disc assembly inspections.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Face Age-Estimation Technology:**
    * This document introduces a novel approach to face age-estimation using computer vision techniques.

* **Challenges in Face Age-Estimation:**
    * Human faces age due to a complex interplay of controllable factors (genetics, ethnicity) and uncontrollable factors (environment, lifestyle).
    * Existing computer-based methods are often computationally expensive or require specific adjustments for accuracy.

* **Contourlet Appearance Model (CAM):**
    * The invention utilizes a CAM algorithm to extract robust facial features that encode age information.
    * CAM combines shape and texture analysis, making it suitable for modeling the complexities of aging faces.

* **Advantages of CAM:**
    * Robust against noise compared to other feature extraction methods like LBP and Gabor wavelets.
    * Effectively distinguishes noise from meaningful signals in images.

* **CAM Processing Steps:**
    * Generates a Modified Active Shape Model (MASM) to represent facial structure.
    * Builds a statistical PCA model of contourlet-level appearance (texture).
    * Combines shape and appearance parameters using another PCA approach to create the final CAM.

* **Age Classification and Aging Functions:**
    * The method classifies subjects into age groups (e.g., youth and adult) using Support Vector Machines (SVMs).
    * Different aging functions are constructed for each age group using Support Vector Regression (SVR).

* **Age-Estimation Process:**
    * Extracts feature vectors from the input image using the trained CAM.
    * Classifies the subject's age group using the SVM-based classifier.
    * Applies the appropriate aging function based on the classified age group to estimate the age.

* **Training Data and System Implementation:**
    * The system is trained using a database of images with assigned landmark points and known ages.
    * The method can be implemented on various computing devices, including smartphones, computers, and servers.

* **Output and Applications:**
    * The system provides an estimated age, optionally with a confidence factor.
    * Potential applications include access control, security systems, and targeted marketing.

* **Advantages Over Existing Methods:**
    * Improved accuracy in age estimation due to the use of CAM and age-specific aging functions.
    * Robustness against image noise, leading to more reliable results.
</summary>

<summary>
* This patent describes a matrix display device for merging two images with different resolutions, primarily for applications requiring simultaneous display of information from different sources. 

   * Examples include merging images from night vision and infrared sensors, or X-ray and MRI images.
   * The invention aims to preserve the higher resolution image's quality while simplifying merging algorithms.
   * It proposes organizing the display matrix into identical pixel arrangements, each dedicated to displaying portions of both images.
   * This allows for efficient hardware implementation and lower power consumption.

* The patent details two exemplary pixel arrangements:

   * One reserves three pixels in a four-pixel arrangement for the higher-resolution image and one for the lower-resolution, typically monochrome, image.
   * The other reserves two pixels each for the two images, suitable for a two-color lower-resolution image.

* Color filters can be used to enhance the display:

   * Pixels dedicated to different images can have different color filters.
   * Complementary color filters can be used for pixels displaying the lower-resolution image to reproduce the higher-resolution image's color when the lower-resolution image is not present.
   * This ensures a visually appealing merged image while maximizing the display area for the higher-resolution image.

* Contrast enhancement techniques are proposed to improve the visibility of the lower-resolution image:

   * The intensity of the higher-resolution image can be locally attenuated around the areas where the lower-resolution image is displayed.
   * This attenuation is dependent on the intensity of the higher-resolution image, ensuring minimal impact on dark backgrounds.
   * This technique enhances the color saturation of the lower-resolution image, making it clearly distinguishable.

* The patent provides specific examples of implementing the invention:

   * Merging a monochrome night vision image with a lower-resolution graphical image.
   * Merging a monochrome night vision image with a lower-resolution infrared image.
   * Merging a monochrome night vision image with both a lower-resolution infrared image and a graphical image.
   * These examples demonstrate the versatility of the invention in handling various image types and resolutions.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Problem:** Imaging devices like xerographic machines experience toner charge degradation during periods of inactivity, leading to inconsistent and darker image quality.

    * Toner charge, crucial for image quality, decreases when the device is idle.
    * Existing toner concentration sensors don't adequately address this issue.
    * Image quality suffers after periods of inactivity, such as overnight.
    * This degradation necessitates intelligent toner charge management.

* **Solution:** Implement an intelligent toner charging system that predicts inactivity periods and adjusts toner charge accordingly.

    * Determine inactivity periods based on user usage patterns.
    * Predict the next user usage to anticipate toner charge needs.
    * Measure toner charge levels and calculate decay during inactivity.
    * Charge the toner to a predetermined level based on predicted decay.

* **Implementation:** The system can be implemented in software or hardware and integrated into existing imaging devices.

    * Monitor user activity and learn usage patterns.
    * Calculate toner charge decay based on inactivity duration.
    * Charge the toner proactively before the predicted next use.
    * Ensure adequate toner charge for optimal printing performance.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Problem:** Conventional rotary magnetic head apparatuses struggle with precise control of multiple MR heads, especially as head count increases, due to limitations in rotary transformer channels and analog signal precision.

	• Existing methods often require a dedicated rotary transformer channel per MR head, making it difficult to scale up the number of heads.
	• Analog control signals are susceptible to noise and precision limitations.
	• Head switching delays in multi-head systems can lead to signal loss and suboptimal MR head operation.

• **Solution:** The invention proposes a rotary magnetic head apparatus that enables independent and precise control of multiple MR heads using a single control channel and digital signals.

	• A control signal generator on the stationary side sends digital control signals over a single rotary transformer channel.
	• A decoder circuit on the rotary side interprets these signals and controls the bias currents of individual MR heads.
	• This approach allows for precise control of each MR head's operating point, optimizing performance.

• **Key Features:**

	• **Single Control Channel:** Utilizes a single rotary transformer channel for transmitting control signals, simplifying the system and allowing for more MR heads.
	• **Digital Control Signals:** Employs digital signals for control information, enhancing precision and noise immunity.
	• **Independent MR Head Control:** Enables individual control of bias currents for each MR head, optimizing their operating points.
	• **Integrated Circuits:** Employs regenerative integrated circuits on the rotary side, integrating MR head control and amplification functions.
	• **Prioritized Head Switching:** Prioritizes the transmission of head switching data to prevent signal loss during head transitions.
	• **Bidirectional Communication:** Allows for monitoring the operating state of MR heads and detecting faults.
	• **Application to Recording Heads:** Extends the control mechanism to recording heads, enabling independent control of recording currents.

• **Advantages:**

	• **Improved Precision:** Digital control signals and independent MR head control enhance the accuracy of signal recording and reproduction.
	• **Increased Head Density:** The single control channel approach allows for incorporating a larger number of MR heads, increasing data density.
	• **Enhanced Reliability:** Prioritized head switching and fault detection mechanisms improve the system's reliability.
	• **Simplified Design:** The use of integrated circuits and a single control channel simplifies the overall system design.

• **Embodiments:**

	• The invention is described through various embodiments, including systems with two or four MR heads,

<summary>
• **Problem:** Prior art cable locators struggle to trace a specific cable when another cable runs closely parallel to it. The output signal gets distorted, making it difficult to pinpoint the desired cable's location.

    • Existing locators use a single transmitter, leading to a combined magnetic field that obscures the individual signals from adjacent cables.

• **Solution:** This invention introduces a system and method to accurately locate and trace one concealed object (like a buried cable) even when another similar object is nearby.

    • The core idea is to induce distinguishable alternating currents in the adjacent objects and then use a receiver that can differentiate the magnetic fields produced by these currents.

• **Key Features:**

    • **Dual Antenna Transmitter (T'):** Employs two antennae (A' and A") spaced apart, each generating a distinct magnetic field (F1 and F2).

    • **Distinguishable Currents:** The antennae are driven by distinguishable RF signals, inducing unique currents in the target cables (C and C').

    • **Specialized Receiver (R):**  The receiver senses the magnetic fields from both cables and generates an output signal only when it detects both distinct fields.

• **Advantages:**

    • **Clear Signal Differentiation:** Produces two distinct null points (N and N") in the output signal, each corresponding to the location of one cable.

    • **Improved Tracing Accuracy:** Enables easier and more precise tracing of a specific cable, even in the presence of adjacent cables.

• **Implementation:**

    • **Signal Differentiation Techniques:**  The invention uses methods like different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation with distinct frequencies, or varied pulse rates to make the induced currents distinguishable.

    • **Optimal Transmitter Positioning:** Placing the transmitter strategically between the cables enhances signal clarity. The invention also guides users on how to find this optimal position.

    • **Receiver Design:** The receiver includes amplifiers, detectors, filters, and oscillators to process the received signals and generate a clear, pulsating audio output for the user.

• **Benefits:**

    • **Enhanced Accuracy:** Makes locating and tracing specific buried cables significantly more accurate, even in crowded underground environments.

    • **Simplified Operation:**  Provides a user-friendly way to differentiate between closely positioned cables, reducing confusion and potential errors.
</summary>

<summary>
• This patent describes an apparatus for hands-free automatic telephone answering and communication using a speakerphone. 
	• It details two embodiments of the invention, one electronic and one electromechanical, both allowing for automatic answering, adjustable call duration, and call extension.
• The electronic embodiment utilizes an optocoupler to detect ringing voltage and trigger a timer circuit to control call duration.
	• An extend switch allows bypassing the timer for longer conversations.
• The electromechanical embodiment uses a neon lamp and photocell to detect ringing and activate a relay for connecting the speakerphone.
	• Similar to the electronic version, it features adjustable call duration and an option to extend calls.
• Both embodiments are designed to be easily connectable to existing telephone systems, offering a convenient hands-free communication solution.
	• They are particularly beneficial for individuals who may have difficulty operating a traditional handset, such as those who are physically handicapped or working in environments where hands-free operation is necessary.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Problem:** Existing undersea communication systems face challenges:
	• Limited multipoint connectivity.
	• Vulnerability to cable cuts.
	• High cost of undersea optical repeaters.

• **Solution:**  A repeaterless trunk and branch ring network with remote pumping:
	• Uses a ring topology for the main trunk cable.
	• Employs branch cables for connecting individual stations.
	• Replaces repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers.

• **Network Architecture:**
	• **Trunk Ring:**  A continuous loop of optical fiber cable connecting multiple hubs.
	• **Branch Cables:** Extend from branching units on the trunk to individual cable stations.
	• **Hubs:** Act as major switching offices, adding/dropping traffic and potentially providing remote pumping.
	• **Cable Stations:** Access points for local traffic, connecting to the trunk via branch cables.

• **Remote Pumping:**
	• Dedicated light sources (e.g., Raman lasers) are coupled to the trunk or branch cables.
	• These sources transmit energy at a wavelength different from communication signals.
	• Remotely located optical amplifiers (e.g., erbium-doped fiber amplifiers) use this energy for signal amplification.

• **Advantages:**
	• **Survivability:** Ring topology and branch structure ensure connectivity even with cable cuts.
	• **Cost-Effectiveness:** Eliminates the need for expensive undersea repeaters.
	• **Flexibility:** Allows for reconfigurable wavelength add/drop branching units.
	• **Sovereignty:** Trunk and branch architecture addresses concerns about data routing between countries.

• **Future Potential:**
	• Advancements in optical fibers, light sources, and amplifiers will further enhance system capabilities.
	• Increased transmission distances and higher data rates will be possible.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Problem:** Existing cover plate designs for electrical wiring devices have exposed mounting screws, which are unsightly and pose a potential shock hazard.

    * Exposed screws detract from the finished appearance of the installation.
    * They can be dangerous if insulation is not properly installed.
    * Prior art solutions are often difficult to install and may not sit flush against uneven walls.
    * Existing designs often lack a convenient way to remove the cover plate once installed.

* **Solution:** A novel two-part cover plate device that eliminates visible fasteners and addresses the shortcomings of prior art.

    * An attachment member is first secured to the wiring device using standard screws.
    * This attachment member features latching pawls and a central tab for secure and easy cover plate installation and removal.
    * The cover plate, with no visible fasteners, then snaps onto the attachment member using a system of saw-tooth racks and latching pawls.
    * This design allows for a flush fit even on uneven walls due to the independent operation of multiple latching points.

* **Advantages:** The invention offers several advantages over existing solutions.

    * **Improved Aesthetics:** No visible fasteners for a clean, finished look.
    * **Enhanced Safety:** Eliminates exposed screws, reducing shock hazard.
    * **Ease of Installation:** Simple snap-on mechanism for quick and easy installation.
    * **Convenient Removal:** A small tool can be used to pry off the cover plate without damage.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Problem:** Conventional TV cameras have a limited picture sequence frequency (25 Hz), making them unsuitable for recording rapid processes. High-speed cameras, while offering higher frequencies, are expensive and rely on film recording, hindering immediate computer analysis.

    • Existing solutions, such as special TV systems with increased resolution, are also costly and require significant modifications.
    • There is a need for a device that enables high-resolution TV recordings of rapid processes in a cost-effective and flexible manner.

• **Proposed Solution:** The invention introduces a device that modifies a conventional TV camera to achieve a higher picture sequence frequency.

    • It employs a cyclic line counter and a beam suppression circuit to selectively scan a fraction (N/p) of the total lines (N) in each frame, effectively increasing the frame rate.
    • A sawtooth generator synchronized with the counter controls the vertical beam deviation, ensuring proper scanning of the selected lines.

• **Advantages:**

    • **Cost-effective:** The device utilizes a conventional TV camera with minimal modifications, making it significantly cheaper than high-speed cameras.
    • **Flexible:** The number of scanned lines (p) can be adjusted, allowing users to optimize the time resolution based on the process speed.

• **Implementation:**

    • The device includes a programmable counter, a delay device, and switches to control the scanning process.
    • The video output can be directly displayed on a TV receiver or digitized and stored for computer analysis.

• **Applications:**

    • The device is suitable for recording and analyzing rapid processes in various fields, including laboratory and industrial settings.
    • It can be used with different imaging modalities, such as IR, UV, and X-ray imaging.

• **Benefits:**

    • Enables the analysis of rapid processes that were previously difficult or expensive to study.
    • Facilitates immediate computer analysis of recorded data, unlike film-based systems.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Problem:** The telecommunications industry is rapidly evolving, with increasing demand for multimedia services. However, integrating these services with existing legacy phone systems poses significant challenges.

	• Existing equipment would need costly replacements.
	• Legacy services would be disrupted during the transition.
	• Standardization and user retraining would be required.
	• Existing solutions primarily focus on circuit-switched calls.

• **Solution:** The invention proposes a system for blending voice and multimedia calls in a packet-switched network while preserving existing infrastructure.

	• A "blender" software component manages both voice and multimedia call components.
	• The blender interacts with both telephony servers (for voice) and multimedia servers (for multimedia).
	• The system leverages Session Initiation Protocol for Telephones (SIP-T) for call setup and teardown.
	• An Intelligent Network (IN) signal can be used to identify and route blended calls.

• **Incoming Blended Call:**

	• A call arrives at the telephony server.
	• The system checks if the recipient supports blended calls.
	• If so, the call is directed to the blender.
	• The blender initiates parallel voice and multimedia call components.

• **Incoming Multimedia Call:**

	• A multimedia request (e.g., instant message) is received.
	• The system routes the request to the appropriate multimedia server.
	• The multimedia server initiates a session and notifies the blender.
	• The blender sets up signaling paths for both voice and multimedia, even if voice is inactive.

• **Outgoing Blended Call:**

	• A user initiates a call from a blended-capable device.
	• The system identifies the call as blended based on user profile.
	• The call is routed to the blender.
	• The blender sets up signaling paths for both voice and multimedia.

• **Outgoing Multimedia Call:**

	• A user initiates a multimedia session.
	• The multimedia server processes the request and engages the blender.
	• The blender sets up signaling paths for both voice and multimedia.
	• The voice component may remain inactive until needed.

• **Key Advantages:**

	• Leverages existing network infrastructure.
	• Supports both voice and multimedia communication seamlessly.
	• Uses SIP-T for efficient call management.
	• Integrates with IN for call routing and handling.

• **Overall Impact:** The invention provides a

<summary>

    * Enables contextual synchronization between connected devices and a central reference point.
* **Dynamic Attributes and Contextual Synchronization:**
    * Clients share dynamic attributes (e.g., location, device type) with the central reference point to receive relevant content bundles.
* **Bundle Structure and Content:**
    * Bundles contain files, download locations, priorities, and actions to be performed after download.
* **Delta List and Efficient Updates:**
    * Clients create a delta list by comparing local files with bundle contents, downloading only necessary updates.
* **Priority-Based Downloading:**
    * Files within bundles are downloaded based on server-assigned priorities.
* **Adaptive Synchronization and Bundle Integrity:**
    * Incomplete bundle downloads are rejected, ensuring data integrity and enabling resumption from the point of failure.
* **Data Compression for Bandwidth Optimization:**
    * Responses and downloaded files are compressed to minimize bandwidth consumption.
* **Scalability and Distributed Processing:**
    * Client-side delta list creation and distributed content hosting enhance scalability.
* **External Partner Integration:**
    * Central reference point can interact with external partners to gather additional attributes and content.
</summary>

* **Proposed Solution:** An anonymous communication system for finders and owners.

    * * Finders access the website, enter the ID, and can send messages to the owner.

* **Benefits for Owners:**
    * * Privacy: Contact information remains hidden from finders.
    * * Control: Owners can choose how to respond to finders.
    * * Multiple Contact Options: Receive messages via email, instant messaging, or text.

* **Benefits for Finders:**
    * * Easy to Use: Simply visit the website and enter the ID.
    * * Anonymous Communication: No need to reveal personal information.

    * * Support for various communication methods (email, IM, text).
    * * Secure storage and management of owner contact information.

* **Overall Impact:** Facilitates the safe and efficient return of lost items while protecting the privacy of both parties involved.

<summary>
* **Introduction**
    * This document describes a new type of electron multiplier called a foil electron multiplier.
    * It offers several advantages over conventional electron multipliers, including higher gain, simpler fabrication, lower cost, and larger area coverage.
    * The invention utilizes a series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure to multiply electrons.
    * The foil electron multiplier can be used in various applications, such as photomultiplier tubes and particle detectors.

* **How it Works**
    * Incident particles (electrons, ions, or photons) pass through thin foils and generate secondary electrons.
    * An electric field accelerates these secondary electrons towards subsequent foils, creating an electron avalanche.
    * The gain of the multiplier depends on factors like foil thickness, applied voltage, and secondary electron emission yield.
    * The design minimizes ion feedback, a common problem in conventional electron multipliers.

* **Advantages over Conventional Multipliers**
    * Higher gain per stage, requiring fewer stages for the same charge amplification.
    * Simpler and cheaper fabrication process compared to microchannel plates (MCPs).
    * Ability to cover larger areas due to the ease of foil fabrication.
    * Intrinsic rejection of ion feedback, eliminating the need for complex channel geometries.

* **Design and Materials**
    * Foils can be round or rectangular, with sizes ranging from 0.5 cm to 2x4 cm.
    * Carbon is the preferred foil material due to its availability in thin and uniform forms.
    * A support grid may be required for structural integrity, depending on the foil thickness.
    * The applied voltage per stage is optimized based on the foil thickness and material.

* **Experimental Results**
    * Tests were conducted using a 50 keV O+ ion beam and carbon foils with a nominal thickness of 0.6 μg/cm2.
    * The measured gain increased with applied voltage and reached a maximum at approximately 650 V per stage.
    * The gain per stage of the foil electron multiplier was found to be higher than that of MCP detectors.
    * The experimental results validated the theoretical model describing the gain mechanism.

* **Applications**
    * Photomultiplier tubes: Convert light into electrical signals with high sensitivity.
    * Particle detectors: Detect and measure charged particles in applications like mass spectrometry.
    * Electron spectrometers: Analyze the energy distribution of electrons.

<summary>
* **3-D Phenomenoscope:** A system for viewing ordinary 2D motion pictures with a 3D effect.
    * Utilizes the Pulfrich effect, where lateral motion appears 3D when viewed through lenses with different light transmission.
    * Processes motion picture images in real-time to control lens darkening and synchronize with on-screen motion.
* **Key Components:**
    * Individually controllable right and left lenses for darkening.
    * Digital photo sensors to capture and digitize motion picture frames.
    * Computer processor and algorithm to analyze images and identify synchronization events.
    * Control mechanism to adjust lens darkening based on detected motion.
* **Advantages over Existing 3D Technologies:**
    * No specialized filming or projection equipment required.
    * Compatible with various film and digital formats, including older movies.
    * Reduced eyestrain due to selective lens darkening only during lateral motion.
* **Pulfrich Effect and Lens Control:**
    * Darkening one lens delays the image reaching that eye, creating a depth illusion for laterally moving objects.
    * Algorithm analyzes successive frames to detect motion direction and adjust lens darkening accordingly.
* **Lens Control Algorithm:**
    * Preferred embodiment uses an intensity edge detection algorithm to track moving objects.
    * Other algorithms and image processing techniques can be implemented.
* **Synchronization Events:**
    * Changes in motion presence, direction, or speed trigger adjustments in lens darkening.
    * Algorithm identifies these events to ensure proper synchronization with on-screen action.
* **Head Movement Compensation:**
    * Head motion can disrupt the 3D effect.
    * Algorithm can track screen position or utilize motion sensors to compensate for head movement.
* **Future Embodiments:**
    * More sophisticated algorithms for detecting complex motion patterns.
    * Multiple lens control algorithms optimized for different film types or effects.
* **Overall Impact:**
    * Makes 3D viewing accessible without special equipment or movie production modifications.
    * Enhances the viewing experience by adding depth and realism to ordinary motion pictures.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Problem:** Traditional wafer dicing using saws has limitations:
    • Slow processing time due to cutting one scribe line at a time.
    • Maintenance and repair downtime reduces throughput.
    • Chipping of thin wafers during cutting reduces yield.
    • Need for an alternative dicing method that avoids these issues.

• **Solution:** A new method and apparatus for dicing semiconductor wafers using pressure:
    • Trenches are formed along scribe lines on the wafer.
    • Adhesive tape is applied to the wafer's back surface.
    • The wafer is placed face down on a soft pad.
    • Mechanical pressure applied to the back surface breaks the wafer along the trenches, separating the dice.

• **Advantages:**
    • Potentially faster than saw-based dicing.
    • Reduced maintenance requirements.
    • Less likely to cause chipping in thin wafers.
    • Enables cleaner breaks and potentially higher yields.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Problem:** Conventional field emission display (FED) devices suffer from damage to field emission elements due to ion bombardment.
    * High-energy electrons emitted from the field emission elements ionize residual gases (e.g., nitrogen, oxygen).
    * These positive ions are attracted to the cathode, causing current surges that damage the field emission elements.
* **Solution:** Introduce a protection structure with reduction plates (electrodes) to deflect the ions.
    * The reduction plates are negatively biased, attracting the positive ions away from the cathode.
    * Ions recombine with electrons at the reduction plates, neutralizing them and preventing damage.
* **Implementation:**
    * **Elongated, parallel reduction plates:** Positioned adjacent to rows of field emission elements on the cathode.
    * **Meshwork-shaped reduction plates:** Form a protective net over the cathode and field emission elements.
* **Advantages:**
    * Prolongs the lifetime of FED devices by preventing ion-induced damage to field emission elements.
    * Improves device stability and performance.
* **Fabrication:** The reduction plates can be fabricated using standard photolithography and etching techniques.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Prior Art Limitations:**
    * Existing CCD image sensors, typically fabricated on flat substrates, face limitations in simultaneously imaging opposing surfaces.
    * While some sensors collect charge carriers from edges, they lack mechanisms to utilize this information for image recording.

* **Invention Objectives:**
    * The present invention aims to address these limitations by enabling information recording through an edge surface of the sensor.

* **Key Features:**
    * The image sensor incorporates a semiconductor substrate with opposed major surfaces and edges, one of which is light-receptive.
    * An image sensor element, positioned adjacent to the light-receptive edge, comprises charge collection and transfer means and an image sensing region.

* **Doping and Waveguiding:**
    *  A P+ layer, strategically placed between the edge surface and adjacent image sensor elements, creates a barrier to electron movement.
    * This design effectively guides charge carriers, generated by light absorption through the edges, towards the center of the substrate and subsequently to the CCDs.

* **Advantages:**
    * The invention enables multi-plane imaging, facilitating applications like simultaneous imaging of opposing surfaces.
    * The use of doped layers to create a waveguide-like structure enhances edge-based image detection.

* **Embodiments and Enhancements:**
    * One embodiment features an image sensor with imaging planes on the top surface and two edge surfaces, utilizing buried-channel CCDs for charge collection and transfer.
    * A second embodiment extends the lightly-doped N-type regions to the edges, improving charge collection and reducing crosstalk.

* **Applications:**
    * The invention finds applications in diverse imaging scenarios, including multi-plane imaging, color imaging, and document scanning.
</summary>
